p: In all variations of our analyses, we found a significant negative association between RA, as an antecedent, and a later diagnosis of PD ( Fig. 3). The risk of getting PD diagnosis was decreased roughly by 30–50% in those individuals who received an RA diagnosis earlier (compared to those who did not receive it). In the inclusive branch of analyses, the odds of getting PD diagnosis 5 (or more) years after the RA diagnosis –was reduced by 35%, odds ratio 0.65 (CI 95% 0.46–0.89), p = 0.006 ( Supplementary Table 1). Similarly, in the conservative branch (with 37% less PD cases), the odds of getting PD diagnosis 5 (or more) years after the RA diagnosis –was reduced by 53% : odds ratio 0.47 (CI 95% 0.28–0.75), p = 0.0006 ( Supplementary Table 2). In general, the association in the conservative branch of analyses (with less individuals and more reliable date of the first PD diagnosis) was stronger than in the inclusive branch.
